A novel tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin-chelated palladium(0) nanoparticles functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANTPPF-Pd(0)) was prepared for the first time. Some necessary methods including Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), etc. were used to verify the micro structure and properties of PANTPPF-Pd(0). Furthermore, with the Heck reaction chosen as a model reaction to determine the catalytic activity of PANTPPF-Pd(0), the experiment results shows that PANTPPF-Pd(0) can efficiently catalyze the Heck reaction with high yields (47–99%) in extensive substrate scope (46 examples) under non-solvent condition. Noteworthily, the average size of Pd(0) nanoparticles observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) slightly increased from 2.32 nm to 2.59 nm after recycled 8 times achieving an 99% isolated yield of Heck reaction catalyzed by PANTPPF-Pd(0), which proves that the PANTPPF-Pd(0) can maintain satisfactory recyclability. Finally, based on the π-π stacking interactions and dipolar-dipolar interaction between tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin moieties in PANTPPF-Pd(0) and substrates, a novel heterogeneous “capture-catalyze” mechanisms was proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Green catalysis Tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin Pd(0) nanoparticles Heck reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction CC bond coupling reaction can be used to the combination of organic molecular fragments, so it can be applied in synthesis of various complex fine chemicals [1,2]. Many researches show that organic ligand-palladium complexes can smoothly catalyze CC bond coupling reactions [3-5], such as Heck reaction [6-8], Suzuki reaction [9-11], Sonogashira reaction [12-14], etc. Among them, Heck reaction was paid more attention in practical chemical production due to its outstanding advantage of being insensitive to water and oxygen [15-17]. In previous reports, various organic ligands containing nitrogenous heterocycle compounds and organophosphine compounds were utilized to chelate palladium salts to prepare suitable catalysts for catalyzing Heck reaction [18,19]. However, many of organophosphine ligands are expensive, which further limits the large-scale application of corresponding catalysts. Therefore, in order to meet the economic and environmental concepts of green chemistry, it is necessary to develop novel heterogeneous economical aza-ligand-palladium catalysts. Recently, many of heterogeneous aza-ligand-palladium catalysts [20-25], based on various supports including MOFs [26,27], silica [28,29], GO [30,31], polymers [32,33], magnetic Fe3O4 [34,35], have been successfully prepared and widely applied in catalysis of CC coupling reactions [36-38]. Compared with traditional catalysis, these heterogeneous catalysts show some outstanding advantages, such as high catalytic activity and easy to separate from the reaction system. However, many of them need to utilize in toxic organic solvent under more harsh reaction conditions, and were hard to reuse multiple times. Therefore, in line with the concept of green chemistry, it is necessary to developed highly efficient and recyclable heterogeneous aza-ligand-palladium catalysts which were suitable for mild conditions. Polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANF), a kind of economical commercial artificial fiber, was widely used in various industrial fields and people's daily life due to its outstanding advantages of light resistance, corrosion resistance, acid resistance, mildew resistance, high strength as well as good thermal stability and good flexibility. Additionally, because PANF was mainly prepared by copolymerization of acrylonitrile and methyl acrylate, it contains abundant cyano groups and methoxycarbonyl groups which can be smoothly chemically functionalized. According to previous researches, PANF can be easily modified by aza-ligands [39,40] and further chelate various metal salts or nanoparticles including Cu(I) [41], Cu(II) [42], Ag(I) [43], Ni(II) [44], Au(0) [45], Ag(0) [46], etc. Most of these catalysts were successfully applied in green solvent, such as ethanol and water, and show satisfactory catalytic activity and reusability. Therefore, it is reasonable for using PANF to prepare novel heterogeneous aza-ligand-palladium catalysts. In our recent work [15], as shown in Scheme 1 , we found that immobilized aza-ligand can effectively chelate and disperse Pd(0) nanoparticles. However, such aza-ligands have smaller chemical structure, which cause them are difficult to efficiently fix large palladium nanoparticles and unable to satisfactorily prevent them from agglomerating during the recycling process. Noteworthily, tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin, a kind of classical aza-ligand, can be used to firmly chelate Pd(0) nanoparticles due to its large and multidentate structure. Therefore, it is suitable for modification into the PANF surface and further preparation of heterogeneous palladium catalyst. However, our previous studies have shown that it is difficult to load large molecular compounds into the surface of the fiber. In this work, a novel tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin-chelated palladium(0) nanoparticles functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANTPPF-Pd(0)) has been prepared for the first time through the cyanuric chloride bridging method. As shown in Scheme 2 , the functionalized fiber PANEAF, PANEA-CCF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(II) and PANTPPF-Pd(0) were prepared sequentially. The pictures of various immobilized fibers was shown in Fig. 1 . The catalytic activity of PANTPPF-Pd(0) was evaluated by Heck reaction, and its microstructure and properties were accurately characterized. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Preparation and characterization of PANTPPF-immobilized Pd(0) catalysts The PANTPPF-Pd(0) fiber catalysts were smoothly prepared by the chelation reaction of PdCl2 with PANTPPF. The functionalities of PANEAF and PANTPPF were calculated by [W%/[M × (1 + W%)]] × 1000, where M is the molecular weight of ethanolamine and tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin, W% is the weight gain of PANF and PANEAF. In addition, the functionality of Pd(0) nanoparticles-functionalized PANF which were accurately measured by inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was 0.1193 mmol/g, indicating that Pd(0) nanoparticles has been successfully grafted into the surface of PANF. The results of functionalized fibers mentioned above are shown in Table 1 . Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) is an important analytical tool that is used to study and characterize the molecular structure and functional groups of compounds. The FTIR spectra of PANF, PANEAF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0), PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 are shown in Fig. 2 . In the FTIR spectra of the original fiber and the immobilized fibers, the stretching vibration of CN at 2243 cm-1 demonstrates that the main structure of PANF was still maintained in the immobilized fibers (Fig. 2a–e). The FTIR spectrum of PANF exhibits an absorption band at 1732 cm-1, which is attributed to the stretching vibration of the CO double bond in the methoxycarbonyl group (Fig. 2a) [47]. The wide peak at the 3000–3500 cm-1 in the FTIR spectra of PANEAF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0) and PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8, which belongs to -NH- in -CONH- due to the admiration of methoxycarbonyl and amino during the modification process (Figs. 2b–e). The absorption peak at 1645 cm-1 in the FTIR spectra of the modified fibers is owing to the stretching vibration of CO in -CONH-, which can indicate that the successful modification of ethanolamine (Fig. 2b) [48]. Furthermore, the presence of absorption peaks in the FTIR spectra of PANTPPF and PANTPPF-Pd(0) at 804 cm-1 and 673 cm-1, which were attributed to CH out-of-plane bending vibration of the aromatic rings (Fig. 2c) [49]. Compared with PANTPPF-Pd(0), the absorption peaks of 804 cm-1 and 673 cm-1 in the FTIR spectrum of PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 got weaker but not disappear, indicating that PANTPPF-Pd(0) fiber still maintained the tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin structure after eight cycles of use (Figs. 2d and e). Therefore, these results can prove that Pd(0) nanoparticle fiber catalyst has good stability and reusability. X-ray diffraction (XRD) is used to analyze the crystal structure of fibers and the patterns of PANF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0), PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 are shown in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3, all fibers have a strong diffraction peak and a weak diffraction peak at 16.96° and 29.52°, which can be attributed to the (100) and (110) crystal planes in the PANF hexagonal lattice [50], suggesting that their crystal planes were not destroyed during the modification process (curves a-d). There are weak characteristic peaks of Pd(0) nanoparticles in the XRD pattern of PANTPPF-Pd(0) at 39.39°, 45.65° and 81.64°, corresponding to (111), (200) and (311) crystal plane, respectively [51-53], which is due to the lower functionality of Pd(0) nanoparticles with small nano-diameter on the PANF (curve c). The characteristic peaks of Pd(0) nanoparticles in the PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 at 39.39°, 45.65° and 81.64° obviously increased, which indicates that some larger Pd(0) particles were probably produced in PANTPPF-Pd(0) during recycling, but it also proved that most palladium was not lost in the recycling process of fibers, demonstrating PANTPPF-Pd(0) has good stability during reuse process. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) is used to determine the chemical composition, chemical state and electronic structure of PANTPPF-Pd(0) and PANTPPF-Pd(0) surface. In the C1s region in XPS spectrum of PANTPPF, peaks at 284.5, 286.0 and 288.0 eV correspond to CH/CC, CN and CN, respectively (Fig. 4 b). The binding energy of the CN group slightly increased from 288.0 eV to 288.8 eV after PANTPPF complexation with palladium, demonstrating the coordination of the palladium to the imine group (-CN+) (Fig. 5 b) [54]. In the N 1 s region in XPS spectrum of PANTPPF, peaks at 398.7, 399.5, 400.5 and 401.5 eV correspond to NC, +NC, NH and NC, respectively (Fig. 4c). It is worth noting that only three peaks of 399.5 eV (+NC and Pd-NC), 400.3 eV (NH) and 401.6 eV (NC) appear in the N 1 s XPS spectrum of PANTPPF-Pd(0), and the peak of 398.7 eV (NC) is missing (Fig. 5c). Additionally, the relative intensity of the peak of 399.5 eV (Pd-NC) increased significantly, confirming palladium component has been successfully chelated by some imine nitrogens (NC) of tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin [54]. The full range spectrum clearly shows the characteristic peaks: C, N, Cl, O of PANTPPF and C, N, Cl, O, Pd of PANTPPF-Pd(0). (Figs. 4a and 5a). There are no obvious changes in the Cl 2p, O 1 s spectra of PANTPPF and PANTPPF-Pd(0). The Cl 2p spectrum has a peak at 198.15 eV because multiple Cl- ions are generated during the reduction of PdCl2 to Pd(0) (Figs. 4d and 5d). Moreover, the O 1 s spectrum has a strong absorption peak at 532.0 eV, which can be attributed to the OC, OH bonds in PANTPPF and PANTPPF-Pd(0) (Figs. 4e and 5e). The Pd 3d spectrum shows two strong characteristic peaks at 335.4 eV and 340.65 eV, corresponding to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 of Pd(0), respectively (Fig. 5f) [55-57]. XPS spectroscopy indicates that Pd nanoparticles have been successfully loaded into the fiber. The high-resolution, high-depth and high-contrast surface images were provided by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM), which is helpful to study and analyze the microscopic characteristics during the modification and reuse of functionalized fibers. The SEM images are shown in Fig. 6 . Under 200 × microscope (Fig. 6a), it is clearly visible that PANEAF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0) and PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 did not suffer from obvious fracture, indicating that the integrity remains well after multiple modifications. Under the 2000 × microscope (Fig. 6b), the surfaces of the functionalized fibers and recycled catalyst were still kept smooth and neat, and the surface of their intrinsic structure was also relatively complete. Under a high-resolution microscope of 20,000 × (Fig. 6c), the slight mechanical damages of PANEAF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0) and PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 were observed. It is worth noting that there is almost no difference between the PANTPPF-Pd(0) and PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8, and the overall morphology and structure are intact, indicating that the fiber has excellent tolerance. Moreover, the elemental mapping picture in SEM (Fig. 7 ) shows the high dispersion of Pd(0) nanoparticles on the PANTPPF-Pd(0), which further proves that PANTPPF-Pd(0) has been prepared successfully. In conclusion, both modified fibers and recycled fiber have high stability. The outstanding advantage of Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) is extremely high resolution, which reveals particle size at the microscopic scale. The TEM images of PANTPPF-Pd(0) show that the Pd(0) nanoparticles do not aggregate and are highly dispersed on the fiber at 100 nm, 50 nm and 20 nm scales. Additionally, Pd(0) nanoparticles in fresh catalyst can be clearly observed at 5 nm and 2 nm scales (Fig. 8 a), and the average particle size is only 2.32 nm (Fig. 8c). When PANTPPF-Pd(0) was reused eight times, there is a very small amount of unavoidable slight self-aggregation of Pd(0) nanoparticles can be observed at the 20 nm scale (Fig. 8b). The particle size of Pd(0) nanoparticles is only increased to 2.59 nm observed at 5 nm and 2 nm scales (Fig. 8d), which not significantly different compared with original catalyst. This demonstrates that PANTPPF-Pd(0) still exhibits high catalytic activity and stability after cycling. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is a critical parameter for material evaluation and selection. The thermal stability of PANF, PANEAF, PANTPPF, PANTPPF-Pd(0), PANTPPF-Pd(0)−8 is shown in Fig. 9 . When the temperature is below 300 °C, the mass residual rate of all fibers is greater than 80%, indicating that the immobilized fibers using PANF as a carrier have high thermal stability. Remarkably, the mass residuals of all fibers are more than 90% at 200 °C, proving that the fiber catalyst can be adapted to most of chemical reactions. 2.2 Catalytic activity of PANTPPF-Pd(0) 2.2.1 The condition optimization of Heck reaction The Heck reaction was used as a template to explore the optimal catalytic conditions for PANTPPF-Pd(0), and the results are shown in Table 2 . The reaction was hard to achieve satisfactory yield when the representative polar/non-polar and protic/aprotic solvents were existed, and can smoothly conducted in the solvent-free condition with the best yield (entries 2–6). Additionally, the Heck reaction is difficult to carry out in the absence of fiber catalyst PANTPPF-Pd(0) (entry 1). Moreover, by changing the reaction time, it was found that the yield of the reaction can reach 99% after 1 h (entries 2, 7, 8). Various catalyst dosages were investigated, and Heck reaction had the highest yield of 99% when the catalyst dosage was 0.05 mol% reacting for 1 h. Increasing the catalyst dosage to 0.2 mol%, the best reaction time was shortened to 30 min which is not significant reduced, so the optimal catalyst dosage still was 0.05 mol% (entries 2, 9–12). Additionally, the TON value can reach up to 12,000 and the TOF value can reach up to 200 min-1 when the catalyst dosage is 0.005 mol%, which is further confirm that PANTPPF-Pd(0) has excellent catalytic activity (entry 12). Furthermore, the effect of different reaction temperature on Heck reaction was investigated, and the best reaction temperature is 120 °C (entries 2, 13). Noteworthily, the effect of different bases on the Heck reaction has been investigated, and triethylamine is the optimal base (entries 2, 14–15). In conclusion, the Heck reaction has the best yield with the catalyst dosage of 0.05% for 1 h of reaction time at reaction temperature of 120 °C under solvent-free conditions (entry 2). 2.2.2 Heck reaction catalyzed by PANTPPF-Pd(0) In order to verify the substrate suitability of PANTPPF-Pd(0) for the Heck reaction, catalytic activity experiments of PANTPPF-Pd(0) on different substrates were conducted under optimal conditions. The results are shown in Table 3 , all of the different olefins reacted with iodized aromatics can be smoothly catalyzed by PANTPPF-Pd(0) and achieved yields of 47%−99%. The reactivity of acrylic acid and iodized aromatics (entries 1–13) is better than that of acrylamide and n‑butyl acrylate (entries 14–22, 23–35), proving that the high polarity of functional groups in the olefins can promote the reaction progress. Furthermore, the effect of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups of iodized aromatics on reaction have been studied, confirming that both of them have good reactivity for Heck reaction (entries 2–13, 15–22, 24–35). Therefore, PANTPPF-Pd(0) catalyst has advantages such as solvent-free, low catalyst dosage (0.05 mol%), excellent catalytic activity and a wide substrates applicability. Noteworthily, PANTPPF-Pd(0) was applied to synthesize various of drug or fine chemical intermediates through Heck reaction in order to explore its practical application value. The experimental results are shown in Table 4 . The synthesis of 10 kinds of important products can be effectively catalyzed by PANTPPF-Pd(0) with the yields ranging from 52% to 99%, which indicates that the PANTPPF-Pd(0) has potential industrial application value. 2.3 Reusability experiment Reusability of catalysts is crucial for the economy and sustainability of catalytic reactions in practical application. Therefore, reusability experiment of PANTPPF-Pd(0) for the Heck reaction has been tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . After completing each cycle reaction, the PANTPPF-Pd(0) catalyst was treated and continue to catalyze the next reaction. The PANTPPF-Pd(0) catalyst still maintains good catalytic activity with yield of 99% after recycling 8 times, indicating that the fiber catalyst has excellent reusability. Additionally, the results of ICP-AES test shows that the Pd content in PANTPPF-Pd(0) only decreased from 0.1193 mmol/g to 0.1164 mmol/g after one cycle catalysis, and the single leaching rate of PANTPPF-Pd(0) is only 2.3%, which confirms that PANTPPF-Pd(0) has excellent stability and reusability used in catalyzing Heck reaction. 2.4 The possible mechanism of PANTPPF-Pd(0)-catalyzed Heck reaction Based on the previous research experiment results [15], a possible “capture-catalyze” mechanism was proposed (Scheme 3 ). Firstly, the tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin moieties in PANTPPF-Pd(0) have can efficiently capture the iodized aromatics and terminal olefins through the π-π stacking interactions and dipolar-dipolar interaction, and then undergoes an oxidative addition reaction with iodized aromatics to form intermediate 1. Secondly, intermediate 1 is combined with terminal olefins for cis addition to form intermediate 2, and intermediate 3 is further obtained by intramolecular space rotation. Next, the intermediate 3 undergoes β-H elimination reaction to release target product and form intermediate 4. Finally, the intermediate 4 continue to lose a HX molecule to recover the original fiber catalyst. Then, the fiber catalyst proceeds to the next catalytic proceed. 2.5 Comparison of PANTPPF-Pd(0) with other catalytic systems As shown in Table 5 , many of heterogeneous palladium catalysts can not exhibit satisfactory catalytic activities under solvent-free conditions, which increase the consumption of solvent and reactants (entries 1–9). Additionally, although the Heck reaction catalyzed by some catalysts can get high yields of target product, longer reaction time, higher dosage of catalysts and limited recycle times affect the practical application value of these catalysts (entries 6–11). Noteworthily, the novel catalyst PANTPPF-Pd(0) can reuse 8 times without significant decreasing in catalytic activity. In summary, PANTPPF-Pd(0) is a green, stable and friendly heterogeneous palladium catalyst (entry 12). 3 Conclusion A novel fiber catalyst of PANTPPF-Pd(0) was prepared for the first time. FTIR, XRD, XPS, SEM and TEM were used to characterize catalyst PANTPPF-Pd(0), and the results verified the functionalized fibers have been successfully prepared. The TEM images indicate that Pd(0) nanoparticles has highly dispersed on the surface of the fiber catalyst. Noteworthily, PANTPPF-Pd(0) has high catalytic activity for the Heck reaction with a low catalyst dosage of 0.05 mol%, short reaction time and solvent-free reaction condition, which was used to catalyze 46 substrates effectively with yields ranging from 47% to 99%. The reusability experiment confirms that the PANTPPF-Pd(0) catalyst has excellent recyclability, which can be used 8 times with yield of 99%. Moreover, a "capture-catalyze" pattern was proposed to explain the catalytic mechanism. coredata.dc:description: A novel tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin-chelated palladium(0) nanoparticles functionalized polyacrylonitrile fiber (PANTPPF-Pd(0)) was prepared for the first time. Some necessary methods including Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), etc. were used to verify the micro structure and properties of PANTPPF-Pd(0). Furthermore, with the Heck reaction chosen as a model reaction to determine the catalytic activity of PANTPPF-Pd(0), the experiment results shows that PANTPPF-Pd(0) can efficiently catalyze the Heck reaction with high yields (47–99%) in extensive substrate scope (46 examples) under non-solvent condition. Noteworthily, the average size of Pd(0) nanoparticles observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) slightly increased from 2.32 nm to 2.59 nm after recycled 8 times achieving an 99% isolated yield of Heck reaction catalyzed by PANTPPF-Pd(0), which proves that the PANTPPF-Pd(0) can maintain satisfactory recyclability. Finally, based on the π-π stacking interactions and dipolar-dipolar interaction between tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin moieties in PANTPPF-Pd(0) and substrates, a novel heterogeneous “capture-catalyze” mechanisms was proposed.
